title: 115_hr2219
content: The Act titled "End Banking for Human Traffickers Act of 2018" aims to increase the financial industry's role in combating human trafficking. The Act amends the Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act to include the Secretary of the Treasury in the President's Interagency Task Force. It also requires a review of procedures to enhance anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing programs to detect financial transactions related to human trafficking. The Act amends the Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act to include the Secretary of the Treasury in the President's Interagency Task Force. It requires a review of procedures to enhance anti-money laundering programs to detect financial transactions related to human trafficking. The Interagency Task Force is tasked with submitting recommendations to relevant committees within 270 days. The Act requires an analysis of anti-money laundering efforts related to severe forms of trafficking in persons by the US Government and financial institutions. It also mandates recommendations to strengthen efforts against money laundering in this context, including feedback from financial institutions on successful programs combatting trafficking. The curr_chunk discusses feedback from stakeholders, including victims of severe forms of trafficking in persons and financial institutions, on policy proposals to enhance efforts to detect and deter money laundering related to trafficking. It also includes recommended changes to training programs at financial institutions. Recommended changes to training programs at financial institutions to better equip employees to deter and detect money laundering related to severe forms of trafficking in persons, expand information sharing among financial institutions and law enforcement agencies, and update statutory laws to address money laundering involving emerging technologies and virtual currencies. The curr_chunk discusses definitions related to the Interagency Task Force to Monitor and Combat Trafficking, including terms like "appropriate Federal banking agency" and "severe forms of trafficking in persons." It also clarifies that the Act does not grant rulemaking authority to the Task Force. The curr_chunk defines "law enforcement agency" as an agency authorized to engage in the prevention, detection, investigation, or prosecution of criminal or civil law violations. The curr_chunk focuses on the coordination of human trafficking issues by the Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence. The curr_chunk amends section 312(a)(4) of title 31, United States Code to combat illicit financing related to severe forms of trafficking in persons. It also adds interagency coordination efforts within the Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence to combat the illicit financing of human trafficking. The curr_chunk further amends section 312(a)(4) of title 31, United States Code to combat severe forms of trafficking in persons by involving various agencies and foreign governments in the effort. It also includes a definition of 'severe forms of trafficking in persons' as per the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000. The curr_chunk adds an additional reporting requirement under the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000. The amendment to the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 includes new reporting requirements related to eliminating money laundering in severe forms of human trafficking. The amendment to the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 includes reporting requirements on investigations, arrests, indictments, and convictions in money laundering cases linked to severe forms of human trafficking. The Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 amendment now includes a new paragraph requiring countries to have a framework to prevent financial transactions related to human trafficking and to prosecute individuals involved in such transactions.
